folioParts.fpdescription: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictorie’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.

The arrangement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition ‘all men are just’ placed on the top of the square is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition ‘some man are just’ at the bottom of the square must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’ is true, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’ must also be true.

In close-up, the dirt and wear and tear on the page are even more visible. We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.

Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). List of propositions in Leiden BPL 84, f. 63r

folioParts.fpdescription: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.

manuscriptsList.title: De consolatione philosophiae and other text(s)
manuscriptsList.contents: This manuscript contains Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy (f. 2r-52r), and the first two books of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philosophiae et Mercurii (f. 53r-93r). F. 94 is an unrelated fragment from Macrobius’ In somnium Scipionis, dated to ca. 1100 (Gumbert, IIMM).The texts in this codex are not core texts for the arts of rhetoric and dialectic, but they illustrate these arts in practice: both authors present rich stories in a mix of prose and poetry, engaging with many of the principles of rhetoric and dialectic in their text. In the Consolation of Philosophy, lady Philosophy argues with the author, who has fallen on bad times, about the value and meaning of life. In Martianus’ De nuptiis, the story of Mercury’s marriage with Lady Philology shows how all the liberal arts contribute to an ultimate knowing of the universe.

folioParts.fpdescription: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.

folioParts.fpdescription: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictorie’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.

The arrangement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition ‘all men are just’ placed on the top of the square is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition ‘some man are just’ at the bottom of the square must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’ is true, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’ must also be true.

In close-up, the dirt and wear and tear on the page are even more visible. We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.

folioParts.fpdescription: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.

manuscriptsList.title: De consolatione philosophiae and other text(s)
manuscriptsList.contents: This manuscript contains Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy (f. 2r-52r), and the first two books of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philosophiae et Mercurii (f. 53r-93r). F. 94 is an unrelated fragment from Macrobius’ In somnium Scipionis, dated to ca. 1100 (Gumbert, IIMM).The texts in this codex are not core texts for the arts of rhetoric and dialectic, but they illustrate these arts in practice: both authors present rich stories in a mix of prose and poetry, engaging with many of the principles of rhetoric and dialectic in their text. In the Consolation of Philosophy, lady Philosophy argues with the author, who has fallen on bad times, about the value and meaning of life. In Martianus’ De nuptiis, the story of Mercury’s marriage with Lady Philology shows how all the liberal arts contribute to an ultimate knowing of the universe.

folioParts.fpdescription: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.

folioParts.fpdescription: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictorie’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.

The arrangement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition ‘all men are just’ placed on the top of the square is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition ‘some man are just’ at the bottom of the square must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’ is true, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’ must also be true.

In close-up, the dirt and wear and tear on the page are even more visible. We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.

Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary.

Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively.

folioParts.fpdescription: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.

title: De consolatione philosophiae and other text(s)
contents: This manuscript contains Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy (f. 2r-52r), and the first two books of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philosophiae et Mercurii (f. 53r-93r). F. 94 is an unrelated fragment from Macrobius’ In somnium Scipionis, dated to ca. 1100 (Gumbert, IIMM).The texts in this codex are not core texts for the arts of rhetoric and dialectic, but they illustrate these arts in practice: both authors present rich stories in a mix of prose and poetry, engaging with many of the principles of rhetoric and dialectic in their text. In the Consolation of Philosophy, lady Philosophy argues with the author, who has fallen on bad times, about the value and meaning of life. In Martianus’ De nuptiis, the story of Mercury’s marriage with Lady Philology shows how all the liberal arts contribute to an ultimate knowing of the universe.

folioParts.fpdescription: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.
